alert.note: Alert for Tehama (California) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Warning issued March 15 at 2:04PM PDT until March 16 at 11:32AM PDT by NWS Sacramento
info.description: ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in California... Sacramento River Near Hamilton City affecting Glenn and Butte Counties. Sacramento River Below Red Bluff Diversion Dam affecting Tehama County. ...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in California... Sacramento River At Ord Ferry affecting Glenn and Butte Counties. Sacramento River At Vina Woodson Bridge affecting Tehama County. Sacramento River At Tehama Bridge affecting Tehama County. .Heavy rainfall from the past 24 hours continues to produce significant rises on the Upper Sacramento river system. Flood wave has reached Vina Woodson Bridge on the Sacramento River and will continue to move downstream. For the Upper Sacramento River...including Bend Bridge, Tehama Bridge, Vina Woodson Bridge, Hamilton City, Ord Ferry, Butte City, Moulton Weir, Colusa Weir, Colusa Bridge, Tisdale Weir...Minor flooding is forecast. ...FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL LATE TOMORROW MORNING... * WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Sacramento River at Vina Woodson Bridge. * WHEN...Until late tomorrow morning. * IMPACTS...At 183.9 feet, Woodson Bridge Park is closed due to flooding. Water is up to the top steps of the recreation center at Woodson Bridge RV Park and spaces 15-33 begin to take on water on the east bank of the river. At 184.9 feet, South Avenue starts to flood east of the river. At 185.9 feet, South Avenue is flooded and closed. The Woodson Bridge RV Park office and spaces 1-14, 34-52, and 62-72 start to flood. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1:00 PM PDT Wednesday the stage was 186.4 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 1:00 PM PDT Wednesday was 186.4 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage this evening and continue falling to 174.1 feet early tomorrow afternoon. - Flood stage is 183.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 186.4 feet on 02/27/2019. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Motorists should not attempt to drive around barricades or drive cars through flooded areas. For more hydrologic information and stage definitions refer to the following web site: wrh.noaa.gov/sto/hydro_data.php The next statement will be issued this evening at 1145 PM PDT.
